comments.body: This would be awesome, even if they just update legacy to 1.20 that would be good as well, seeing the legacy combat with the warden and the legacy textures and how they work with the warden would also be cool

DO IT, YOU COWARDS.

How hasn't this page exploded?

Java really needs a modding API - just because mod loaders exist and have existed is no excuse - those mod loaders are client-by-client and make it nigh-impossible to set up mods in multiplayer settings, not to mention the accessibility issues. Not everyone is willing to download third-party software to mod.

Plus, it'd unify every mod under one loader, unlike now, where there's like 6 now, with 2 of them being mainstream major options, Forge and Fabric. Those 2 have created the biggest tear between the modding community, resulting in many mods that'd be great together to be unusable together.

Create a Java API, darnit. Even if it's like Bedrocks extremely limited API right now, just let us have the skeleton, and continue to build upon it until we can create great experiences like Create within the confines of Minecraft's own engine.

If there were a capable Java API, 3rd party mod loaders would be abandoned and every active modder would re-create their mod within the API.

Mojang, please do this.

Man, Microsoft is really holding you guys back.

Yeah! That'd be cool, and it's too bad Mojang's original idea got shelved.

Ideally this would also be on Bedrock - then we'd have the return of the Bedrock API that got scrapped, like, a year after launch.
We need big YouTubers to push this post out, we need this implemented.

This is a simple solution to a very unfair problem.

I agree that 'big' updates need little updates and adjustments here and there over time. Just yesterday, my bros and I were talking about the new Caves & Cliffs update, and we thought of little things we would like added to make the update even better and more fun. I've also noticed that with every new 'big' update, other older 'big' updates seem to be pushed away and forgotten, such as woodland mansions spawning farther and farther away. Just little things that need to be considered when planning future updates:)

I've been researching my Dungeon's problem.  Apparently when purchasing it through the Java launcher it had me buy it on www.minecraftdungeons.net; which is associated with my XBOX account.  However, my Microsoft account has Minecraft for Win 10.  Hence the reason I have three launchers.  At least before my XBOX launcher was connected to my Java launcher... but not any longer :/

True, that wouldn't fit Minecraft, but when you beat the game you get what is pretty close to a cutscene, with the 2 celestials ( or whatever they are supposed to be called) talking. This means that maybe something basic could be done when other events happen. Maybe you could get a similar event to happen when you beat a boss for the first time? That would be tricky though because when you beat a boss you need to grab its drop and do other things immediately, so maybe it could just be when entering a new dimension? For example, you could see a small cutscene of the celestials taking notice of you when you enter the nether, since that is required to go to the end.

I disagree.  Really, I couldn't care less how the textures look, as long as they aren't terrible.  I also believe that the client isn't always right.  Sometimes, Mojang announces a new feature, and players say that it will be terrible.  But it always turns out to be okay.  I prefer to trust their game developing expertise rather than the opinion of some player who doesn't know good gameplay principles.  Of course, players often suggest good ideas - that's what this website is for, after all.  But ultimately, Mojang will judge whether they should be added (and if they should, are they more important than plans for future updates), and 99% of the time I feel that they made the right choice.

I don't believe that less detail is better, if that were true than minecraft 1.13 and 14 would have sucked. I think that the quality of detail is what matters, not the quantity. that's why at least in my opinion 1.8 - 1.12 were the dark ages of minecraft because they added mostly useless features to the game.
Minecraft never wasn’t popular, it simply may have seemed that way due to the Fortnite craze. Honestly, I think the people at Mojang are doing a fine job of keeping Minecraft fresh.
This didn't age well...

I think it has less to do with detail and more to do with the gameplay experience itself. Adding new possible experiences and content has improved the game in many ways - the problem is how everything acts together. For example, because of the loot you can find in villages and shipwrecks, mining has become a far less valid strategy for obtaining some of the most important resources. Survival used to be harder. It used to be more rewarding to survive. Instead of removing features, Mojang should take a look at how features fit in the overall game and balance them accordingly.

An example: I think villages and pillager outposts should be more rare - there are many valuable things you can obtain from villagers, but they aren't rare enough for a player to put a lot of work into building any one of them. There is no point in guarding a village from zombies and pillagers when there are so many of them around. Making villages rarer would enhance player experience with villages, not harm it.
